myopenmath.statement:
Kira was driving at 60 feet per second on the highway the other day. If the speed limit is 45 miles per hour, was she driving too fast? Answer the question by converting 60 feet per second into miles per hour.
To answer this question, we will convert the numerator into miles and the denominator into hours.
If we begin with the fraction \displaystyle\frac{{{60}\ \text{feet}}}{{{1}\ \text{second}}}, we can multiply by three unit fractions to complete the conversion. What are these fractions? Choose the correct fractions in the calculation below:
\displaystyle\frac{{{60}\ \text{feet}}}{{{1}\ \text{second}}}\times
60 min/1 sec
60 sec/1 min
1 sec/60 min
1 min/60 sec
\displaystyle\times
1 hr/60 min
60 min/1 hr
60 hrs/1 min
1 min/60 hrs
\displaystyle\times
1 ft/5280 mi
5280 ft/1 mi
5280 mi/1 ft
1 mi/5280 ft
///
The conversion calculation looks like:
\displaystyle\frac{{{60}\ \text{feet}}}{{{1}\ \text{second}}}\times\displaystyle\frac{{{60}\ \text{sec}}}{{{1}\ \text{min}}}\times\frac{{{60}\ \text{min}}}{{{1}\ \text{hr}}}\times\frac{{{1}\ \text{mi}}}{{{5280}\ \text{ft}}}
Was Kira driving too fast?
Answer:
Yes
No
...because she was driving mi/hr (round using significant figures; all speeds are accurate to two sig figs) when the limit was \displaystyle{45} mi/hr
